TITLE: Implement Two-way Claude Code Session Sync between Desktop and Mobile Apps
BODYSTRING: # Implement Two-way Claude Code Session Sync between Desktop and Mobile Apps  Closes #1178  ## ğŸ¯ Overview  This PR implements full two-way synchronization of Claude Code sessions between the desktop Tauri app and mobile Expo app using Convex as the real-time backend. Users can now:  - **Desktop â†’ Mobile**: Sessions created on desktop appear in mobile app with real-time updates - **Mobile â†’ Desktop**: Sessions initiated from mobile automatically start Claude Code on desktop - **Real-time Sync**: Messages sync bidirectionally in real-time across both platforms - **Persistent State**: Sessions and messages persist across app restarts  ## ğŸ—ï¸ Technical Implementation  ### Backend (Convex) - **Extended Schema**: Added `claudeSessions`, `claudeMessages`, and `syncStatus` tables - **Comprehensive Functions**: Session management, message syncing, mobile session requests - **Real-time Queries**: Automatic updates when data changes  ### Desktop Integration - **Convex Hooks**: Monitor for mobile-initiated sessions - **Session Syncing**: Automatically sync new desktop sessions to Convex - **Claude Code Hook Scripts**: Real-time sync via Claude Code hooks - **Mobile Session Handling**: Create local Claude Code sessions from mobile requests  ### Mobile App - **Complete UI Overhaul**: Replaced basic demo with full Claude Code interface - **Session Management**: List, create, and view sessions with real-time updates - **Message Interface**: Send messages and view conversation history - **Desktop Integration**: Request desktop Claude Code sessions  ### Hook-based Sync - **Real-time Hooks**: Scripts triggered by Claude Code events (`UserPromptSubmit`, `PostToolUse`, `Stop`) - **Automatic Syncing**: Messages and session state sync to Convex without manual intervention - **Debug Tools**: Session inspection scripts for development  ## ğŸš€ Key Features  ### Mobile App - **ğŸ“± Session List**: View all Claude Code sessions (desktop + mobile) - **â• Create Sessions**: Request new desktop Claude Code sessions - **ğŸ’¬ Real-time Messaging**: Send/receive messages with desktop sessions - **ğŸ”„ Live Updates**: Real-time sync of session state and messages - **ğŸ“Š Session Status**: Visual indicators for active/inactive/error states  ### Desktop App   - **ğŸ”— Convex Integration**: Automatic session syncing to backend - **ğŸ“² Mobile Monitoring**: Detect and create sessions from mobile requests - **âš¡ Hook Scripts**: Real-time sync via Claude Code hooks - **ğŸ”„ Bidirectional Sync**: Messages flow both ways seamlessly  ### Developer Experience - **ğŸ”§ Hook Setup**: Comprehensive setup instructions and examples - **ğŸ› Debug Tools**: Session inspection and logging scripts - **ğŸ“š Documentation**: Detailed setup and troubleshooting guides - **ğŸ” Type Safety**: Full TypeScript support across the stack  ## ğŸ“ Files Changed  ### Backend - `packages/convex/convex/schema.ts` - Extended schema for Claude Code sessions - `packages/convex/convex/claude.ts` - Comprehensive Convex functions  ### Desktop App - `apps/desktop/src/App.tsx` - Integrated Convex sync and mobile session monitoring - `apps/desktop/package.json` - Added Claude Code SDK dependency - `apps/desktop/claude-hooks/` - Hook scripts and documentation  ### Mobile App - `apps/mobile/App.tsx` - Updated to use new Claude Code interface - `apps/mobile/components/ClaudeCodeMobile.tsx` - Complete mobile UI implementation  ## ğŸ§ª Testing  ### Build Verification - âœ… Desktop TypeScript compilation passes - âœ… Mobile TypeScript compilation passes   - âœ… No type errors or build warnings  ### Functional Testing - ğŸ”§ Hook scripts tested with sample data - ğŸ“± Mobile UI renders correctly with proper styling - ğŸ–¥ï¸ Desktop integration compiles without errors  ## ğŸ”§ Setup Instructions  ### 1. Convex Backend The new schema and functions are automatically deployed with Convex.  ### 2. Desktop Hook Configuration Add to `~/.claude/settings.json`:  ```json {   "hooks": {     "UserPromptSubmit": [{"matcher": "*", "hooks": [{"type": "command", "command": "/path/to/openagents/apps/desktop/claude-hooks/sync-to-convex.cjs"}]}],     "PostToolUse": [{"matcher": "*", "hooks": [{"type": "command", "command": "/path/to/openagents/apps/desktop/claude-hooks/sync-to-convex.cjs"}]}],     "Stop": [{"matcher": "*", "hooks": [{"type": "command", "command": "/path/to/openagents/apps/desktop/claude-hooks/sync-to-convex.cjs"}]}]   } } ```  ### 3. Environment Variables Set `VITE_CONVEX_URL` and `EXPO_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL` to your Convex deployment URL.  ## ğŸ¬ Demo Workflow  1. **Mobile User** opens app, creates new session with project path 2. **Desktop App** automatically detects new mobile session   3. **Claude Code** starts on desktop for the requested project 4. **Real-time Sync** messages flow between mobile and desktop 5. **Both Platforms** show live session state and conversation history  ## ğŸš€ Next Steps  - [ ] End-to-end testing with real Claude Code sessions - [ ] Performance optimization for large message histories   - [ ] Offline support and sync conflict resolution - [ ] Enhanced mobile UI features (message editing, session management)  ## ğŸ“ Technical Notes  - Uses Convex real-time subscriptions for instant updates - Claude Code hooks provide zero-latency sync from desktop - Mobile-initiated sessions trigger desktop Claude Code via Tauri backend - Full TypeScript support with auto-generated Convex types - Comprehensive error handling and logging  This implementation provides the foundation for seamless cross-platform Claude Code collaboration\! ğŸ‰  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>  <!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai --> ## Summary by CodeRabbit  * **New Features**   * Introduced real-time synchronization of Claude Code sessions between desktop, mobile, and Convex backend.   * Added a mobile interface for viewing, creating, and interacting with Claude Code sessions and messages.   * Enabled mobile-initiated session requests and seamless session syncing across devices.   * Provided detailed session and message management, including status tracking and metadata.   * Added backend API support for managing Claude sessions, messages, and sync status with Convex.   * Integrated desktop app with Convex to sync sessions created locally or from mobile devices.   * Added CLI tools for syncing hook data and inspecting session data structures.  * **Documentation**   * Added comprehensive setup and usage instructions for Claude Code hooks and Convex integration.   * Updated README to highlight two-way sync and Convex backend features.   * Added detailed guidance on CodeRabbit AI code review process.  * **Chores**   * Added example configuration and sample data files to demonstrate hook setup and data structure.   * Updated dependencies to support new Claude Code features.   * Enhanced mobile app submission scripts for streamlined iOS deployment.   * Added new build and submit scripts for mobile app in root package configuration. <!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

TITLE: feat: Add CI/CD Pipeline and Optimize Project Configuration
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR adds a comprehensive CI/CD pipeline and optimizes the project configuration for better development workflow and deployment practices.  ## Key Changes  ### ğŸš€ CI/CD Pipeline - **GitHub Actions Workflow**: Complete CI/CD pipeline with testing, linting, security scanning - **Multi-Architecture Support**: AMD64 and ARM64 Docker builds - **GitHub Container Registry**: Automated image publishing to `ghcr.io/billduke13/dyvine` - **Security Scanning**: Trivy vulnerability scanner for code and container images - **Automated Deployment**: Staging deployment on main branch pushes, production on releases  ### ğŸ³ Docker Optimization - **Migration from Conda to pip**: Replaced conda environment with Python virtual environment - **Multi-stage Build**: Optimized Dockerfile with proper layer caching - **Security Improvements**: Non-root user, reduced attack surface - **Size Reduction**: Smaller final image size with better performance  ### ğŸ“‹ Project Configuration - **Enhanced .gitignore**: Added FastAPI-specific patterns, security files, runtime data - **Security Workflow**: Weekly dependency and container vulnerability scans - **Streamlined Dependencies**: Removed unnecessary conda configuration  ## Testing Strategy  The CI/CD pipeline includes: - âœ… Code linting (ruff, black, isort) - âœ… Type checking (mypy) - âœ… Unit tests with coverage reporting - âœ… Security vulnerability scanning - âœ… Container image security analysis  ## Deployment  ### Staging - Automatically deploys on main branch pushes - Uses image tagged with commit SHA for traceability  ### Production   - Triggered by GitHub releases - Uses semantic versioning tags - Includes build provenance and SBOM generation  ## Breaking Changes  None. All changes are additive and maintain backward compatibility.  ## Migration Notes  1. The new CI/CD pipeline will start running automatically after merge 2. Docker images will be available at `ghcr.io/billduke13/dyvine` 3. No action required for existing deployments  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat: Add automatic PR creation to installer for better visibility
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR enhances the Code Conductor installer with automatic pull request creation functionality, addressing the limitation where installations only exist locally until manually committed and pushed.  ## Problem  When Code Conductor is installed, the `.conductor` directory and configuration files are created locally. Other agents or developers cannot see or use the system until these changes are merged into the main branch. This creates a manual step that can be overlooked, especially in automated environments like Claude Code.  ## Solution  Added new command-line flags to `conductor-init.sh`: - `--create-pr`: Automatically creates a pull request after installation - `--auto-merge`: Enables auto-merge on the created PR (implies `--create-pr`) - `--pr-branch <name>`: Allows specifying a custom branch name  ## Changes  ### Installer Script (`conductor-init.sh`) - Added PR creation logic after the commit step - Automatically creates a feature branch if on main/master - Pushes changes and creates a descriptive PR - Optionally enables auto-merge for seamless activation - Adds appropriate labels (`conductor:setup`, `automation`)  ### Documentation Updates - **README.md**: Added PR creation example for Claude Code users - **docs/INSTALLATION.md**:    - Added new flags to installation options   - Created dedicated "Pull Request Workflow" section explaining the feature   - Updated examples to show PR creation usage - **CLAUDE_CODE_PROMPT.md**: Updated all installation commands to use `--create-pr --auto-merge`  ## Benefits  1. **Immediate Visibility**: Code Conductor becomes visible to all agents/developers as soon as the PR is created 2. **Automation-Friendly**: Perfect for Claude Code and other automated environments 3. **Audit Trail**: Clear git history showing when Code Conductor was installed 4. **Zero Manual Steps**: With auto-merge, the entire installation is hands-free  ## Testing  The installer checks for: - GitHub CLI availability and authentication - Whether we're on the default branch (creates new branch if so) - Successful push before attempting PR creation - Graceful fallback if any step fails  ## Example Usage  ```bash # Install with automatic PR and auto-merge curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ryanmac/code-conductor/main/conductor-init.sh | bash -s -- --auto --create-pr --auto-merge  # Install with PR but manual merge curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ryanmac/code-conductor/main/conductor-init.sh | bash -s -- --auto --create-pr  # Specify custom branch name curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ryanmac/code-conductor/main/conductor-init.sh | bash -s -- --auto --create-pr --pr-branch my-conductor-setup ```  ## Related Issues  This addresses the user feedback about needing to merge the `.conductor` directory before other agents can see it.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat: Add CI/CD Pipeline and Optimize Project Configuration
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR adds a comprehensive CI/CD pipeline and optimizes the project configuration for better development workflow and deployment practices.  ## Key Changes  ### ğŸš€ CI/CD Pipeline - **GitHub Actions Workflow**: Complete CI/CD pipeline with testing, linting, security scanning - **Multi-Architecture Support**: AMD64 and ARM64 Docker builds - **GitHub Container Registry**: Automated image publishing to `ghcr.io/memenow/dyvine` - **Security Scanning**: Trivy vulnerability scanner for code and container images - **Automated Deployment**: Staging deployment on main branch pushes, production on releases  ### ğŸ³ Docker Optimization - **Migration from Conda to pip**: Replaced conda environment with Python virtual environment - **Multi-stage Build**: Optimized Dockerfile with proper layer caching - **Security Improvements**: Non-root user, reduced attack surface - **Size Reduction**: Smaller final image size with better performance  ### ğŸ“‹ Project Configuration - **Enhanced .gitignore**: Added FastAPI-specific patterns, security files, runtime data - **Security Workflow**: Weekly dependency and container vulnerability scans - **Streamlined Dependencies**: Removed unnecessary conda configuration  ## Testing Strategy  The CI/CD pipeline includes: - âœ… Code linting (ruff, black, isort) - âœ… Type checking (mypy) - âœ… Unit tests with coverage reporting - âœ… Security vulnerability scanning - âœ… Container image security analysis  ## Deployment  ### Staging - Automatically deploys on main branch pushes - Uses image tagged with commit SHA for traceability  ### Production   - Triggered by GitHub releases - Uses semantic versioning tags - Includes build provenance and SBOM generation  ## Breaking Changes  None. All changes are additive and maintain backward compatibility.  ## Migration Notes  1. The new CI/CD pipeline will start running automatically after merge 2. Docker images will be available at `ghcr.io/memenow/dyvine` 3. No action required for existing deployments  ## Files Changed  - âœ… Added comprehensive GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow (`.github/workflows/ci-cd.yml`) - âœ… Added security scanning workflow (`.github/workflows/security.yml`) - âœ… Optimized Dockerfile for pyproject.toml workflow - âœ… Enhanced .gitignore with project-specific patterns - âœ… Removed Codecov integration as requested - âœ… Added project documentation and build tools  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat: Resource-Based Chips Jokers (#121)
BODYSTRING: ## Summary Implements Resource-Based Chips Jokers that provide chip bonuses based on various resource conditions.  ## Jokers Implemented - Bull: +18 Chips for each dollar you have - Blue Joker: +3 Chips for each remaining card in deck - Hiker: +4 Chips for every card played - Flash Card: +3 Mult per reroll in the current round - Popcorn: +20 Mult, -4 Mult per round played  ## Notes - All jokers include comprehensive unit tests - Implemented using the new JokerTrait system - Tests verify proper scoring behavior and edge cases  Closes #121

TITLE: fix: handle Supabase AuthApiError exceptions properly in auth verification
BODYSTRING: ## Summary This PR fixes the authentication error handling in the `/api/v1/auth/verify` endpoint to properly handle Supabase authentication errors and return appropriate HTTP status codes.  ## Problem - iOS app was receiving generic 500 "Authentication service error" responses when Supabase token validation failed - This prevented the app from properly handling authentication failures (e.g., expired tokens, invalid tokens) - The backend was catching `AuthApiError` exceptions as generic exceptions instead of handling them specifically  ## Solution - Added specific import for `gotrue.errors.AuthApiError` from the Supabase Python SDK - Added a dedicated exception handler for `AuthApiError` that:   - Returns 401 status codes for authentication failures (instead of 500)   - Provides specific error messages based on the error type:     - "Invalid authentication token" for invalid/malformed JWTs     - "Token has expired. Please sign in again." for expired tokens     - "User not found. Please sign up first." for non-existent users     - Generic "Authentication failed. Please sign in again." for other auth errors - Improved error logging to help with debugging  ## Testing - Tested locally with invalid tokens to verify proper 401 responses - Confirmed that the error messages are appropriate for each scenario - Verified that valid tokens still work correctly  ## Impact - iOS app will now receive proper 401 responses for authentication failures - Users will see more helpful error messages when their session expires - Better debugging capabilities with improved error logging  ## Related Issues Fixes the authentication issue reported where users couldn't sign in despite successful Supabase authentication.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat(payload-indexing): implement fast filtering with comprehensive test infrastructure improvements
BODYSTRING: ## Summary - **ğŸš€ PRIMARY FEATURE**: Implemented payload indexing for 10-100x faster filtered searches (Issue #56) - **ğŸ§ª INFRASTRUCTURE**: Comprehensive test suite reorganization and quality improvements - **ğŸ”§ TESTING**: Fixed 15+ broken tests across config, services, and provider components - **ğŸ“‹ MANAGEMENT**: Created GitHub issues for systematic test coverage completion  ## ğŸ¯ Payload Indexing Implementation (Issue #56)  ### Core Features - **Automatic Index Creation**: Payload indexes automatically created on collection creation - **Comprehensive Index Management**: Create, list, drop, reindex operations via QdrantService - **Performance Monitoring**: Index statistics and benchmarking tools - **MCP Integration**: New MCP tools for index management and performance analysis  ### Indexed Fields for Fast Filtering - **Core Fields**: `doc_type`, `language`, `framework`, `version`, `crawl_source` - **System Fields**: `site_name`, `embedding_model`, `embedding_provider` - **Timestamps**: `created_at`, `last_updated` for temporal filtering - **Content Metrics**: `word_count`, `char_count` for size-based filtering  ### Enhanced Filter Building - Refactored `_build_filter()` into specialized helper methods:   - `_build_keyword_conditions()` - Exact matching for indexed fields   - `_build_text_conditions()` - Full-text search for content fields   - `_build_timestamp_conditions()` - Date range filtering   - `_build_content_metric_conditions()` - Size-based filtering   - `_build_structural_conditions()` - Document structure filtering  ### CLI Tools & Scripts - **Migration Script**: `scripts/migrate_payload_indexes.py` - Migrate existing collections - **Benchmarking**: `scripts/benchmark_payload_indexing.py` - Performance validation - **Integration**: Enhanced MCP server with index management tools  ### Performance Targets - **10-100x improvement** in filtered search performance - **Sub-millisecond** index-based filtering for common queries - **Automatic optimization** for frequently used filter combinations  ## ğŸ§ª Test Infrastructure Improvements  ### Directory Restructure - **Before**: Flat structure with 25+ test files in `/tests/` - **After**: Organized hierarchy:   - `tests/unit/` - Component-level unit tests   - `tests/integration/` - Cross-component integration tests     - `tests/performance/` - Performance benchmarks and validation   - `tests/fixtures/` - Shared test data and utilities  ### Enhanced Test Configuration - Updated `pyproject.toml` with optimized pytest settings:   - `./scripts/test.sh quick` - Fast unit tests   - `./scripts/test.sh clean` - Summary only (no verbose output)   - `./scripts/test.sh coverage` - Full coverage report   - `./scripts/test.sh failed` - Run only previously failed tests  ### Test Fixes & Debugging - TITLE: feat: AWS Serverless MCP
BODYSTRING: ## Summary Creates a MCP server to assist in deploying application onto AWS Serverless  ### Changes  The AWS Serverless Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server is an open-source tool that combines AI assistance with serverless expertise to streamline how developers build serverless applications. It provides contextual guidance specific to serverless development, helping developers make informed decisions about architecture, implementation, and deployment throughout the entire application development lifecycle. With AWS Serverless MCP, developers can build reliable, efficient, and production-ready serverless applications with confidence.  The set of tools provided by the Serverless MCP server can be broken down into four categories:  1. Serverless Application Lifecycle   - Intialize, build, and deploy Serverless Application Model (SAM) applications with SAM CLI   - Test Lambda functions locally and remotely  2. Web Application Deployment & Management   - Deploy fullstack, frontend, and backend web applications onto AWS Serverless using Lambda Web Adapter.   - Update frontend assets and optionally invaliate CloudFront caches   - Create custom domain names, including certificate and DNS setup. 3. Observability   - Retrieve and logs and metrics of serverless resources 4. Guidance, Templates, and Deployment Help   - Provides guidance on AWS Lambda use-cases, selecting an IaC framework, and deployment process onto AWS Serverless   - Provides sample SAM templates for different serverless application types from [Serverless Land](https://serverlessland.com/)   - Provides schema types for different Lambda event sources and runtimes  ### User experience  * AI-powered serverless development: Provides rich contextual information to AI coding assistants to ensure your serverless application aligns with AWS best practices.  * Comprehensive tooling: Offers tools for initialization, deployment, monitoring, and troubleshooting of serverless applications. * Architecture guidance: Helps evaluate design choices and select optimal serverless patterns based on application needs. Offers recommendations on event sources, function boundaries, and service integrations. * Operational best practices: Ensures alignment with AWS architectural principles. Suggests effective use of AWS services for event processing, data persistence, and service communication, and guides implementation of security controls, performance tuning, and cost optimization. * Security-first approach: Implements built-in guardrails with read-only defaults and controlled access to sensitive data.  ## Checklist  If your change doesn't seem to apply, please leave them unchecked.  * [x] I have reviewed the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) * [x] I have performed a self-review of this change * [x] Changes have been tested * [x] Changes are documented  Is this a breaking change? (Y/N) N  **RFC issue number**: https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/issues/293  Checklist:  * [ ] Migration process documented * [ ] Implement warnings (if it can live side by side)  ## Acknowledgment  By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of the [project license](https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/blob/main/LICENSE).

TITLE: Performance optimization: Improve indexing speed and fix BM25 issues
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR implements comprehensive performance optimizations for Japanese document indexing and search, addressing slow BM25 indexing performance, memory issues during large-scale document processing, and reranker performance bottlenecks.  ### Key Performance Improvements  - **BM25 Indexing Speed**: Reduced from ~44s to ~23s for 870 documents (48% improvement) - **Memory Management**: Prevented 36GB temporary file usage through batch processing - **Reranker Performance**: Multiple optimizations reducing search time from 17.7s to sub-12s - **Tokenization Speed**: Added caching to avoid re-tokenizing identical content - **UI/UX**: Removed unnecessary "ctrl+r to expand" text and improved progress display  ### Technical Optimizations  #### Database & Memory Management - **Batch Processing**: Implemented configurable batch processing (10,000 entries) for BM25 index storage - **Schema Optimization**: Changed `positions` column from TEXT/JSON to INTEGER[] for better performance - **Memory Efficiency**: Fixed GROUP BY optimization preventing 36GB temporary file creation - **Progress Tracking**: Added detailed progress logging for all database operations  #### Tokenization Performance - **Caching**: Added term frequency caching to avoid duplicate tokenization of identical content - **Early Termination**: Skip very short texts early in tokenization process - **Progress Frequency**: Increased reporting frequency (every 5 chunks vs 10) for better user feedback - **Position Tracking**: Temporarily disabled for performance gains during indexing  #### Reranker Optimizations - **Batch Size**: Increased from 32â†’64 for better throughput - **Retrieval Reduction**: Optimized hybrid search multiplier (2xâ†’1.5x when reranking) - **Configuration Consistency**: Fixed reranker_top_k_multiplier default (3â†’2) - **Timing Analysis**: Added detailed performance logging to identify bottlenecks  #### Search Performance - **Hybrid Search**: Reduced document retrieval for reranking scenarios - **Progress Display**: Enhanced hierarchical progress with detailed stage tracking - **Error Handling**: Fixed logger import issues in reranker timing code  ### Configuration Updates  #### Reranker Settings (Optimized) ```python "reranker_top_k_multiplier": 2,     # Reduced from 3 for better performance "reranker_batch_size": 64,          # Increased from 32 for better throughput "reranker_use_onnx": True,          # ONNX optimization enabled "reranker_max_length": 512,         # Optimized sequence length ```  #### BM25 Settings (Enhanced) ```python "bm25_k1": 1.2,                     # Term frequency saturation "bm25_b": 0.75,                     # Document length normalization "use_japanese_tokenizer": True,     # MeCab morphological analysis "bm25_min_token_length": 2,         # Minimum token length ```  #### Indexer Settings (Performance) ```python "chunk_size": 1024,                 # Optimal chunk size "chunk_overlap": 256,               # Overlap for context preservation "batch_size": 128,                  # Embedding batch size "max_workers": 8,                   # Parallel processing threads ```  ### Progress Display Enhancements  #### Detailed BM25 Indexing Stages - **Tokenization**: Real-time chunk processing progress with caching - **Vocabulary Building**: Term frequency analysis and filtering - **Index Storage**: Batch-wise database operations with progress tracking - **Memory Management**: Efficient handling of large document collections  #### User Experience Improvements - Removed unnecessary "ctrl+r to expand" text from search and index results - Enhanced hierarchical progress display with clear stage indicators - Real-time feedback during long-running operations - Better error messaging and recovery  ### Performance Benchmarks  #### Before Optimization - **Indexing**: 870 documents in ~44 seconds - **Memory Usage**: 36GB temporary files during BM25 queries - **Reranking**: 17.7 seconds for 5 results - **Progress**: Minimal feedback during long operations  #### After Optimization - **Indexing**: 870 documents in ~23 seconds (48% faster) - **Memory Usage**: <100MB through batch processing (99.7% reduction) - **Reranking**: <12 seconds with detailed timing logs - **Progress**: Real-time updates every 5 chunks with stage details  ### Test Coverage & Quality  - **Comprehensive Tests**: Added pytest tests for batch processing functionality - **Memory Efficiency**: Tests verify large dataset handling without memory issues - **Update Mode**: Tests ensure proper handling of incremental updates - **Code Quality**: All tests pass with improved type safety and linting  ### Breaking Changes  **None** - All changes are backward compatible with existing configurations and data.  ### Technical Debt Addressed  - Fixed inconsistent default values between config sections - Improved error handling in reranker operations - Enhanced logging throughout the codebase - Better separation of concerns in search operations  ### Future Optimization Opportunities  - **Parallel Tokenization**: Potential MeCab parallelization for further speed improvements - **Advanced Caching**: Extended caching strategies for frequently accessed content - **Hardware Acceleration**: GPU utilization for reranker operations - **Index Compression**: Further memory optimizations for very large datasets  This comprehensive optimization makes the system practical for daily use with large Japanese document collections, addressing all major performance bottlenecks in indexing, search, and reranking operations.  ### Impact Summary  **For End Users:** - Faster indexing with clear progress indication - Sub-12 second search responses with reranking - Better resource utilization preventing system overload - Cleaner, more informative user interface  **For Developers:** - Detailed performance logging for troubleshooting - Configurable batch sizes for different hardware setups - Improved code maintainability and error handling - Better test coverage for complex operations  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: ğŸ¤– Add Automated Log Monitoring System with Intelligent GitHub Issue Creation
BODYSTRING: ## Summary This PR introduces a comprehensive automated log monitoring system that intelligently detects, analyzes, and creates GitHub issues for application errors without creating noise from transient problems.  ## Key Features  ### ğŸ”„ Automated Monitoring - **Frequency**: Runs every 15 minutes via Laravel scheduler - **Smart Detection**: Groups similar error patterns together - **Threshold-based**: Only triggers on 3+ occurrences (configurable)  ### ğŸ§  Intelligent Issue Creation - **Validation**: Confirms errors still occur before creating issues - **Severity Filtering**: Critical/High auto-create, Medium needs 10+ occurrences   - **Duplicate Prevention**: 24-hour cooldown per error pattern - **Bot Attribution**: Clear marking as automated issues  ### ğŸ“Š Error Analysis - **Pattern Recognition**: Groups errors by removing variable data (timestamps, IDs, etc.) - **Severity Assessment**: Critical, High, Medium, Low based on error type and context - **Category Classification**: Database, Queue, Mail, Authentication, API, Application - **Validation Logic**: Database table checks, class existence verification  ### ğŸ¯ Smart Resolution Detection - **Database Errors**: Validates if tables actually exist - **Class Errors**: Checks if missing classes are now available - **Temporal Validation**: Only considers patterns active if recent (last 5 minutes) - **Self-Resolution**: Marks resolved issues automatically  ## Real-World Demo  During development, the system detected: 1. **Performance table error** from 3 days ago 2. **Validated** the table actually exists now   3. **Marked as resolved** without creating unnecessary GitHub issue 4. **CommandNotFoundException** from test command 5. **Correctly skipped** single occurrence, medium severity error  This demonstrates the intelligence in avoiding false positives and spam.  ## Commands Added  ### Core Monitoring \`\`\`bash # Automated monitoring (runs via scheduler) php artisan logs:monitor --interval=15 --threshold=3 --validate  # Manual monitoring with dry-run php artisan logs:monitor --dry-run \`\`\`  ### Status & Management   \`\`\`bash # View monitoring dashboard php artisan logs:monitor-status  # Clear monitoring cache php artisan logs:monitor-status --clear-cache \`\`\`  ## Benefits  ### For Development - **Proactive Detection**: Catch issues before users report them - **Noise Reduction**: Smart filtering prevents spam from temporary problems - **Structured Documentation**: Consistent, detailed GitHub issues - **Historical Tracking**: Cache-based tracking of resolved vs. ongoing issues  ### For Operations - **24/7 Monitoring**: Automated detection without manual log review - **Intelligent Alerts**: Only critical/high severity or frequent medium severity - **Self-Healing Detection**: Automatically resolves transient issues - **Performance Insights**: Track error patterns and resolution rates  ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>  <!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai --> ## Summary by CodeRabbit  - **New Features**   - Introduced automated log monitoring with error pattern detection, validation, and intelligent GitHub issue creation, running every 15 minutes.   - Added commands to analyze recent errors, generate detailed AI-assisted error reports, and create GitHub issues via multiple authentication methods.   - Provided a command to display log monitoring status, statistics, and manage monitoring cache.   - Added demo and test commands to inject realistic and specific types of errors for testing and demonstration purposes.   - Enhanced GitHub integration configuration with new repository and token options.  - **Documentation**   - Added comprehensive documentation detailing the automated log monitoring system, workflow, configuration, and usage instructions. <!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

TITLE: Phase 3: Dashboard UX Testing & Scraping Analysis - Critical Issues Documented
BODYSTRING: ## Phase 3: Dashboard User Experience Testing & Scraping Capability Analysis  ### Summary Comprehensive user experience testing of the JobBot dashboard revealing critical navigation failures, combined with breakthrough analysis of job site scraping capabilities identifying 556K+ accessible jobs.  ### Changes Made - **Dashboard UX Testing**: Complete systematic testing of all dashboard components - **Scraping Analysis**: HTTP accessibility testing of major job platforms - **LinkedIn Integration**: Direct API access testing revealing 513K+ job listings - TITLE: feat: Amazon EKS MCP Server
BODYSTRING: <!-- markdownlint-disable MD041 MD043 --> Fixes  ## Summary  ### Changes  The Amazon EKS MCP server provides AI code assistants with resource management tools and real-time cluster state visibility. This provides  large language models (LLMs) with essential tooling and contextual awareness, enabling AI code assistants to streamline application development through tailored guidanceâ€”from initial setup through production optimization and troubleshooting.  Integrating the EKS MCP server into AI code assistants enhances development workflow across all phases, from simplifying initial cluster setup with automated prerequisite creation and application of best practices. Further, it streamlines application deployment with high-level workflows and automated code generation. Finally, it accelerates troubleshooting through intelligent debugging tools and knowledge base access. All of this simplifies complex operations through natural language interactions in AI code assistants.  ### User experience  New capabilities added:  * Enables users of AI code assistants to create new EKS clusters, complete with prerequisites such as dedicated VPCs, networking, and EKS Auto Mode node pools, by translating requests into the appropriate AWS CloudFormation actions. * Provides the ability to deploy containerized applications by applying existing Kubernetes YAML files or by generating new deployment and service manifests based on user-provided parameters. * Supports full lifecycle management of individual Kubernetes resources (such as Pods, Services, and Deployments) within EKS clusters, enabling create, read, update, patch, and delete operations. * Provides the ability to list Kubernetes resources with filtering by namespace, labels, and fields, simplifying the process for both users and LLMs to gather information about the state of Kubernetes applications and EKS infrastructure. * Facilitates operational tasks such as retrieving logs from specific pods and containers or fetching Kubernetes events related to particular resources, supporting troubleshooting and monitoring for both direct users and AI-driven workflows. * Enables users to troubleshoot issues with an EKS cluster.  ## Checklist  If your change doesn't seem to apply, please leave them unchecked.  * [x] I have reviewed the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) * [x] I have performed a self-review of this change * [x] Changes have been tested * [x] Changes are documented  Is this a breaking change? (Y/N) N  **RFC issue number**: https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/issues/305  Checklist:  * [ ] Migration process documented * [ ] Implement warnings (if it can live side by side)  ## Acknowledgment  By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of the [project license](https://github.com/awslabs/mcp/blob/main/LICENSE).

TITLE: Refactor: Simplify Step Class Hierarchy and Reduce Complexity (#59)
BODYSTRING: ## Summary - Refactored Step class hierarchy to follow SOLID principles and reduce complexity - Created new simplified implementations alongside existing ones for gradual migration  ## Changes Made  ### 1. Step Execution Engine - Extracted execution mechanics (error handling, events) into `StepExecutionEngine` - Separates concerns between step logic and execution infrastructure  ### 2. Simplified Base Step Class   - Reduced from 150+ lines to < 100 lines - Only contains the essential contract (execute, validate, name) - Removed all execution mechanics to the engine  ### 3. Debate Step Refactoring - Extracted proposal collection into `ProposalCollector` component - Created `VotingSystem` with pluggable strategies (MajorityVoting, WeightedVoting) - DebateStep now just orchestrates these components (~100 lines vs 200+)  ### 4. Parallel Step Refactoring - Created `ParallelStrategy` abstraction with multiple implementations:   - `DomainParallelStrategy`: Analyze from different perspectives   - `TaskSplitStrategy`: Split task into subtasks   - `LoadBalancedStrategy`: Distribute based on agent capabilities - ParallelStep simply delegates to chosen strategy  ### 5. Step Factory - Simple factory for creating configured steps - Makes common patterns easy: `StepFactory.debate(agents)` - Provides convenient methods for different configurations  ## Benefits  1. **Simplicity**: Each class has one clear purpose 2. **Testability**: Components can be tested in isolation   3. **Flexibility**: Easy to create new step types or strategies 4. **Maintainability**: Less code in each class 5. **Extensibility**: New strategies without changing steps  ## Test Results  All new components have comprehensive test coverage: - 16 tests for refactored steps pass - 5 tests for step engine pass - Examples demonstrate new API usage  ## Migration Path  1. New implementations in separate files (`steps_v2.py`) 2. Existing Step API remains unchanged 3. Can migrate gradually as needed 4. Factory provides easy migration path  Fixes #59  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: Fix #434: Implement lore consistency tracking system
BODYSTRING: # Pull Request Template  ## Description Implementation of a comprehensive lore management system for tracking narrative facts and maintaining story coherence. This system provides CRUD operations for lore facts, AI integration for consistent narrative generation, and a user interface for managing world lore.  ## Related Issue Closes #434  ## Type of Change - [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)  ## TDD Compliance - [x] Tests written before implementation - [x] All new code is tested - [x] All tests pass locally - [x] Test coverage maintained or improved  ## User Stories Addressed - As a player, I want basic lore consistency tracking so that the narrative maintains coherence with established facts - Players can manually add and manage lore facts through the LoreViewer component - AI systems receive relevant lore context to maintain narrative consistency - Facts are automatically extracted from narrative text and stored  ## Implementation Notes ### Core Components: - **LoreStore**: Zustand store with CRUD operations, search/filtering, and AI context generation - **LoreViewer**: React component for displaying and managing lore facts with responsive design - **LoreIntegratedNarrativeGenerator**: Enhanced AI service that includes lore context in prompts - **Type System**: Comprehensive TypeScript definitions for lore management  ### Key Features: - Fact categorization (characters, locations, events, rules, items, organizations) - Source tracking (narrative, manual, AI-generated, imported) - Advanced search and filtering capabilities - Automatic fact extraction from narrative text - AI integration for maintaining narrative consistency - IndexedDB persistence for client-side storage  ## Checklist - [x] Code follows the project's coding standards - [x] File size limits respected (max 300 lines per file) - [x] Self-review of code performed - [x] Comments added for complex logic - [x] Documentation updated (if required) - [x] No new warnings generated - [x] Accessibility considerations addressed  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: Fix: Add support for pytest collection errors in JSON extractor
BODYSTRING: ## Summary Fixes the issue where pytest-analyzer would not detect collection errors (import errors, module not found, etc.) that occur during the test collection phase. **Now includes enhanced fallback suggestions when LLM APIs are unavailable** (merged from development).  ## Problem The pytest-analyzer was only looking at the `tests` section of pytest JSON reports for failed tests, but collection errors are stored in the `collectors` section with a different structure. Additionally, when LLM APIs were unavailable, users would get "No fix suggestions found" even for common, easily-fixable issues.  ## Solution ### Collection Error Detection - âœ… Enhanced `JsonResultExtractor` to process collection errors from the `collectors` section - âœ… Implemented `_create_failure_from_collector()` method to handle collection error structure - âœ… Added intelligent error type detection that prioritizes specific errors (ModuleNotFoundError) over general ones (ImportError) - âœ… Enhanced error message extraction from the `longrepr` field for collection errors - âœ… Updated both `_parse_json_report()` and `_parse_json_data()` methods  ### LLM Fallback Suggestions (Merged from Development) - âœ… **NEW**: Enhanced fallback suggestion system when LLM APIs are unavailable - âœ… **NEW**: Intelligent detection of common error patterns (ModuleNotFoundError, ImportError, SyntaxError) - âœ… **NEW**: Package manager specific suggestions (pip, poetry, pixi, uv, hatch) - âœ… **NEW**: High confidence scores for reliable automated suggestions - âœ… **NEW**: Seamless integration with collection error detection  ### Combined Benefits - âœ… Collection errors are now detected AND receive intelligent fallback suggestions - âœ… Works reliably even without LLM API access - âœ… Provides practical, actionable installation commands - âœ… Maintains high-quality suggestions through error pattern matching  ## Testing - âœ… All existing JSON extractor tests pass (no regressions) - âœ… Collection errors are now properly detected and processed - âœ… Error types are correctly identified (ModuleNotFoundError vs ImportError) - âœ… Analysis pipeline processes collection errors like regular test failures - âœ… **NEW**: Fallback suggestions work seamlessly with collection errors - âœ… **NEW**: Enhanced suggestion quality for missing dependencies  ## Example Results  ### Before Fix ```bash pytest-analyzer --project-root /path/to/project tests/test_with_missing_deps.py --use-llm # Output: No fix suggestions found. ```  ### After Fix (With Development Merge) ```bash pytest-analyzer --project-root /path/to/project tests/test_with_missing_deps.py --use-llm  # Output: # Grouped 1 failures into 1 distinct groups # Generating LLM suggestions for group: ModuleNotFoundError < /dev/null  < /dev/null |  Missing_Module_fastapi # # Found 1 fix suggestions: # â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Suggestion 1/1 â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ # Test: tests/test_with_missing_deps.py # Error: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'fastapi' # # Suggested fix (Enhanced Fallback): # Install the missing module 'fastapi' using your preferred package manager. # # Code changes: # File: installation_commands # - pip install fastapi # - poetry add fastapi   # - pixi add fastapi # - uv add fastapi # - hatch add fastapi # # Confidence: High (automated pattern detection) ```  ### Even Without LLM API ```bash pytest-analyzer --project-root /path/to/project tests/test_with_missing_deps.py # Still provides intelligent fallback suggestions\! ```  ## Impact This fix makes pytest-analyzer significantly more useful for developers dealing with: - âŒ Import errors during test collection - âŒ Missing dependency issues   - âŒ Module not found errors - âŒ Syntax errors in test files - âŒ Environment setup problems  **Key improvement**: Even without LLM API access, users now get practical, actionable suggestions for common collection failures, making the tool much more reliable in offline or API-limited environments.  ## Changes Included ### This Branch (Collection Error Detection) - Enhanced JSON extractor for collection errors - Intelligent error type prioritization - Robust error message extraction  ### Merged from Development (Enhanced Fallback System) - Advanced fallback suggestion patterns - Multi-package manager support - High-confidence automated suggestions - Seamless LLM/fallback integration  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat: VCR integration tests and enhanced gallery-dl configuration
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR introduces comprehensive VCR (Video Cassette Recorder) integration tests for the boss-bot download system and significantly enhances the gallery-dl configuration with support for additional platforms and advanced features.  ### ğŸ¯ Key Changes  #### VCR Integration Testing - **Fixed `bossctl fetch` command**: Resolved gallery-dl API configuration issues that were causing `set()` method errors - **Enhanced Test Coverage**: Added VCR-based integration tests for real Twitter/X download scenarios - **Fixed Test Failures**: Corrected import paths and test assertions in CLI fetch tests - **Improved Error Handling**: Better exception handling and user-friendly error messages in the fetch command  #### Enhanced Gallery-dl Configuration - **Additional Platforms**: Added comprehensive support for Instagram, YouTube, and Pixiv - **Advanced Features**: Implemented postprocessors, filters, archive management, and proxy configuration - **Better Rate Limiting**: Added sleep controls and request throttling options - **Comprehensive Options**: Support for metadata extraction, content filtering, and path management  ### ğŸ”§ Technical Improvements  #### Configuration Enhancements - **PostprocessorConfig**: Support for metadata extraction, ZIP/CBZ archives, and media conversion (ugoira, ffmpeg) - **FilterConfig**: Content filtering by size, date, image range, and extension mapping - **ArchiveConfig**: Duplicate detection and download tracking capabilities - **PathConfig**: Advanced path handling and filename character restrictions - **ProxyConfig**: Network proxy and source address binding support  #### Platform Support - **Instagram**: API mode selection, content type filtering, metadata extraction - **YouTube**: yt-dlp integration with format selection and quality options - **Pixiv**: Artist platform support with authentication and content filters - **Enhanced Twitter/Reddit**: Extended configuration options for existing platforms  #### Bug Fixes - **Gallery-dl API Integration**: Fixed `config.set()` method usage to properly merge configuration options - **Pydantic V2 Compatibility**: Updated configuration models to use `populate_by_name` instead of deprecated `allow_population_by_field_name` - **Test Infrastructure**: Fixed VCR test patterns and mock configurations  ### ğŸ§ª Testing  - **373 tests passing** with 7 skipped - **Enhanced VCR integration** for real-world download scenarios - **Comprehensive configuration testing** for all new platform options - **Fixed CLI fetch command tests** with proper error handling validation  ### ğŸš€ Benefits  - **More Robust Downloads**: Better error handling and configuration options - **Extended Platform Support**: Support for additional social media and content platforms - **Advanced Features**: Metadata extraction, content filtering, and duplicate detection - **Better Testing**: VCR integration ensures reliable testing with real network scenarios - **Future-Proof**: Comprehensive configuration foundation for additional features  This enhancement significantly expands the bot's capabilities while maintaining backward compatibility and improving reliability.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: feat: add --catalog-only flag to run bundle command
BODYSTRING: Add a new --catalog-only flag to the 'operator-sdk run bundle' command that creates only the catalog source without creating a subscription. This allows users to deploy the catalog source for manual subscription management or for use with other tools.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>  <!--  Welcome to the Operator SDK\! Before contributing, make sure to:  - Read the contributing guidelines https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.MD - Rebase your branch on the latest upstream master - Link any relevant issues, PR's, or documentation - Check that the commit message is concice and helpful:     - When fixing an issue, add "Closes #<ISSUE_NUMBER>"     - Sign your commit https://github.com/apps/dco - Follow the below checklist if making a user-facing change   Note, the location for ansible operator related logic has changed. For ansible operator related changes, please create the Pull Request in https://github.com/operator-framework/ansible-operator-plugins   -->  **Description of the change:**  This PR adds a new `--catalog-only` flag to the `operator-sdk run bundle` command. When this flag is used, the command creates only the catalog source without creating a subscription, operator group, or install plan.  The implementation includes: - Added `CatalogOnly bool` field to the `Install` struct in `internal/olm/operator/bundle/install.go` - Added `--catalog-only` flag binding with description "create only the catalog source without creating a subscription" - Created `RunCatalogOnly` method that creates the catalog source using the existing `CatalogCreator.CreateCatalog` method and logs that subscription creation is being skipped - Modified `Run` method to check if `CatalogOnly` is true and route to `RunCatalogOnly` instead of `InstallOperator`  **Motivation for the change:**  Currently, the `operator-sdk run bundle` command creates both a catalog source and a subscription. However, there are use cases where users need only the catalog source:  1. **Testing tokenized auth install flows**: For testing the OpenShift Console's operator install frontend with tokenized authentication (see [operator-hub-subscribe.tsx#L502-L555](https://github.com/openshift/console/blob/f11a6158ae722200d342519971af337f8ff61d3a/frontend/packages/operator-lifecycle-manager/src/components/operator-hub/operator-hub-subscribe.tsx#L502-L555)), automatic subscription creation is not desirable. The frontend needs to handle the subscription creation flow itself to properly manage authentication tokens. 2. **Manual subscription management**: Users may want to create the catalog source first and then manually create subscriptions with specific configurations 3. **Integration with other tools**: Other automation tools or operators may need to create subscriptions programmatically after the catalog source is available 4. **Testing**: Developers may want to test catalog source creation independently from operator installation 5. **Multi-tenant scenarios**: In environments where different teams manage catalog sources and subscriptions separately  This change provides more flexibility in how users can deploy and manage operators using the SDK.  **Checklist**  If the pull request includes user-facing changes, extra documentation is required: - [ ] Add a new changelog fragment in `changelog/fragments` (see [`changelog/fragments/00-template.yaml`](https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/tree/master/changelog/fragments/00-template.yaml)) - [ ] Add or update relevant sections of the docs website in [`website/content/en/docs`](https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk/tree/master/website/content/en/docs)

TITLE: setup agents with docker
BODYSTRING: ## Summary This PR sets up AutoGen agents with Docker containers and includes various fixes and improvements to the VM management system.  ## Recent Changes (2025-06-03)  ### Fixed VM Management Script UID Issues - **Problem**: VM management scripts (stop_vm.sh, restart_vm.sh, start_vm.sh) were failing with "VirtualBox VM was created with a user that doesn't match" errors - **Root Cause**: Scripts were using `sudo` unnecessarily, causing UID mismatch (VM created with user UID 1000, scripts running as root UID 0) - **Solution**: Updated all VM lifecycle scripts to try without sudo first, only using sudo as fallback  ### Changes Made: 1. **All VM Management Scripts** (start_vm.sh, stop_vm.sh, restart_vm.sh, savestate_vm.sh):    - Try operations without sudo first    - Only use sudo as fallback if permission errors occur    - Proper permission cleanup after sudo operations    - Fixed directory path resolution to ensure scripts run from correct location  2. **virtualmachine/test/test-vm-lifecycle.sh**:    - Comprehensive test script for all VM lifecycle operations    - Tests stop, start, restart, and savestate operations    - Validates VM state transitions  ### Fixed VM Provisioning Permission Issues (2025-06-02) - **Problem**: `provision_vm.sh` was failing with permission errors when Vagrant tried to update box files owned by root - **Solution**: Added automatic permission fixing and better error handling in the provisioning script  ### Changes Made: 1. **virtualmachine/guest_scripts/setup_dev.sh**:    - Added `dpkg --configure -a` to fix interrupted package installations    - Removed forced Guest Additions version installation that caused compatibility issues    - Let VMs use Guest Additions that come with the Bento box    - Added automatic recovery for existing GA installations  2. **virtualmachine/host_scripts/provision_vm.sh**:    - Added `fix_vagrant_box_permissions()` function to detect and fix root-owned files in Vagrant boxes directory    - Enhanced error handling with permission detection and automatic retry logic    - Added multiple fallback strategies: fix permissions â†’ retry â†’ sudo â†’ fix ownership    - Captures detailed logs to help diagnose issues    - Ensures ownership is corrected after any sudo operations  3. **virtualmachine/test/test-vm-provision.sh**:    - Comprehensive test script for VM provisioning process    - Validates software installation, services, and configuration  ### Testing: - Successfully tested provisioning with `testuser` - VM was created and started without manual intervention - Successfully tested all VM lifecycle operations (stop, start, restart, savestate) - Scripts now automatically handle permission issues that previously caused failures  ## Previous Work in This PR  ### Docker Setup for AutoGen Agents - Created comprehensive Docker setup for running AutoGen agents - Single Dockerfile with all necessary dependencies - Dynamic docker-compose.yml using environment variables - Automated container provisioning and management scripts  ### Repository Restructure - Reorganized to focus exclusively on AutoGen agents - Removed Claude Code support and related files - Clear separation: `docker/` for containers, `virtualmachine/` for VMs - Cleaned up obsolete components (vm_cli, host_service)  ### VM Management Improvements - Enhanced destroy_vm.sh with VirtualBox verification and cleanup - Added Vagrant cache cleanup and permission fixes - Better handling of orphaned VMs and stale Vagrant entries  ### Environment and Configuration - Streamlined environment variable handling - Fixed Docker permission issues - Improved AutoGen agent startup reliability  ## Known Issues Addressed - Vagrant box permission errors causing provisioning failures - Orphaned VirtualBox VMs after vagrant destroy - Docker container environment variable loading - AutoGen agent startup issues in containers - dpkg interrupted errors during VM provisioning - VirtualBox Guest Additions compatibility issues - VM management script UID mismatch errors  ## Testing Performed - VM provisioning with various users - VM destruction and cleanup - VM lifecycle operations (start, stop, restart, savestate) - Docker container builds and startup - AutoGen agent functionality in both VMs and containers  This PR significantly improves the reliability and usability of the development environment setup.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: refactor(mcp): complete unified MCP server modularization and API/SDK migration
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR completes the comprehensive refactoring of the unified MCP server into a modular architecture following FastMCP 2.0 best practices, along with migration to direct API/SDK usage instead of MCP proxying.  ## Key Changes  ### ğŸ—ï¸ MCP Server Modularization - Split monolithic `unified_mcp_server.py` into focused tool modules:   - `search.py` - Document search and similarity operations   - `collections.py` - Collection management   - `embeddings.py` - Embedding generation   - `documents.py` - Document management     - `projects.py` - Project-based operations   - `cache.py` - Cache management   - `deployment.py` - Deployment patterns   - `analytics.py` - Analytics and monitoring   - `utilities.py` - Utility functions   - `advanced_search.py` - Advanced search strategies   - `payload_indexing.py` - Payload indexing operations - Created `tool_registry.py` for centralized tool registration - Removed old `server.py` and `service_manager.py`  ### ğŸ“ Service Layer Reorganization - Moved core services to `services/core/`:   - `qdrant_service.py`   - `qdrant_alias_manager.py`   - `project_storage.py` - Moved utilities to `services/utilities/`:   - `hnsw_optimizer.py`   - `rate_limiter.py`   - `search_models.py`  ### ğŸ”„ API/SDK Migration - Migrated from MCP proxying to direct SDK usage - Updated all service imports and dependencies - Fixed cache API usage in EmbeddingManager  ### âœ… Test Updates - Added comprehensive unit tests for new modular structure - Updated existing tests for new import paths - Fixed test expectations for changed defaults - Removed outdated integration tests  ### ğŸ“š Documentation - Enhanced browser automation API documentation - Updated architecture documentation  ## Testing  All critical tests are passing. Some minor integration test failures remain due to API changes but these are non-blocking and can be addressed in follow-up PRs.  ## Migration Notes  The new modular structure provides: - Better separation of concerns - Easier maintenance and testing - More flexible tool composition - Cleaner API boundaries  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>  ## Summary by Sourcery  Refactor the unified MCP server into a fully modular architecture with direct API/SDK integration and update services, tests, and documentation accordingly.  New Features: - Split the monolithic MCP server into individual tool modules and implemented a centralized registry for dynamic FastMCP tool registration - Introduced a unified ClientManager with lazy initialization and lifecycle management to replace the old proxy-based service manager - Migrated all service interactions from MCP proxying to direct SDK/API calls via the new client manager  Bug Fixes: - Fixed cache API usage in the embedding manager to use the correct internal cache methods - Updated default configuration and Pydantic model validations to correct test expectations  Enhancements: - Reorganized core services into services/core and utilities into services/utilities with consistent import paths - Rebuilt unit and integration test fixtures to use mock clients and align with the new modular structure - Enhanced browser automation API docs and architecture documentation to reflect the refactored server design  Documentation: - Updated architecture and API documentation to describe the new modular server and direct SDK usage  Tests: - Removed outdated integration tests and added comprehensive tests for modular tools, client manager lifecycle, and service layers  Chores: - Removed legacy server.py and service_manager.py files - Cleaned up deprecated monolithic code and adjusted project structure

TITLE: chore(repo): setup claude code
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR integrates Claude Code AI assistant capabilities into the Nx repository through GitHub Actions and workspace configuration.  ## Changes Made  ### ğŸ¤– GitHub Actions Integration - **Added `.github/workflows/claude.yml`**: GitHub Actions workflow that triggers Claude Code on:   - Issue comments containing `@claude`   - Pull request review comments containing `@claude`    - Pull request reviews containing `@claude`   - New issues with `@claude` in title or body - Configured appropriate permissions for repository access and PR/issue management - See [Claude Code GitHub Actions documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/cli-usage#github-actions) for usage details  ### ğŸ“ Project Documentation & Configuration - **Added `CLAUDE.md`**: Comprehensive instructions for Claude Code including:   - Repository-specific guidance and best practices   - Essential commands for development workflow   - Testing procedures (individual projects â†’ affected projects â†’ e2e tests)   - GitHub issue resolution workflow   - Pre-push validation requirements - **Added `.claude/settings.json`**: Claude Code permissions and environment configuration - **Added `.mcp.json`**: Model Context Protocol server configuration for Nx workspace integration  ### ğŸ”§ Workspace Setup - **Updated `package.json`**: Added `nx-mcp` dependency for enhanced workspace integration - **Updated `pnpm-lock.yaml`**: Lock file changes for new dependency - **Updated `.gitignore`**: Added Claude-specific ignore patterns - **Updated `CODEOWNERS`**: Assigned ownership of Claude-related files to @FrozenPandaz - **Updated `CONTRIBUTING.md`**: Enhanced contribution guidelines with technology stack information  ## Benefits  - Enables AI-assisted development and issue resolution through GitHub - Provides Claude with deep understanding of Nx workspace structure via MCP - Establishes clear development workflows and validation procedures - Maintains security through configured permissions and environment settings  ## Usage  After this PR is merged, team members and contributors can: 1. TITLE: Feature: Implement test coverage reporting and TDD development environment
BODYSTRING: ## Summary Implements comprehensive test coverage reporting and TDD development environment infrastructure as requested in issues #112 and #113.  ## Changes Made  ### Test Coverage Reporting (#112) - âœ… Configured Vitest coverage with v8 provider - âœ… Added coverage thresholds (starting at 5% statements/branches/lines, 10% functions) - âœ… Set up HTML, JSON, and LCOV coverage reports in `./coverage/` - âœ… Added coverage scripts: `test:coverage`, `test:coverage:offline`, `test:coverage:watch` - âœ… Coverage reports automatically exclude type files and test files - âœ… Updated `.gitignore` to exclude coverage reports  ### TDD Development Environment (#113) - âœ… Installed and configured Husky for git hooks - âœ… Set up pre-commit hook to run tests before commits - âœ… Created test file templates for unit, integration, and mock tests - âœ… Added TDD workflow scripts: `./scripts/create-test.sh`, `./scripts/setup-tdd.sh` - âœ… Enhanced package.json with comprehensive test commands:   - `test:watch:offline` - Watch mode for offline tests   - `test:watch:ui` - Visual test interface   - `test:watch:changed` - Watch only changed files     - `test:single` - Run tests once   - `test:debug` - Verbose output for debugging - âœ… Created comprehensive TDD guide documentation (`docs/tdd-guide.md`) - âœ… Set up VS Code workspace settings for optimal TDD workflow  ## Test Commands Available  ### Basic Testing - `npm test` - Run all tests (used in pre-commit hooks) - `npm run test:offline` - Run tests excluding real API calls - `npm run test:single` - Run tests once (no watch mode)  ### TDD Development   - `npm run test:watch:offline` - Watch mode for offline tests (recommended for TDD) - `npm run test:watch:ui` - Visual test interface - `npm run test:watch:changed` - Watch only changed files - `npm run test:debug` - Verbose output for debugging  ### Coverage Testing - `npm run test:coverage:offline` - Coverage for offline tests - `npm run test:coverage:watch` - Watch mode with coverage  ### TDD Workflow - `npm run create:test unit src/utils/my-module MyModule` - Create new test from template - `npm run setup:tdd` - Complete TDD environment setup  ## Documentation  ### TDD Guide Comprehensive guide created at `docs/tdd-guide.md` covering: - Quick start instructions - TDD cycle: Red -> Green -> Refactor - Test file organization - Best practices - VS Code integration - Troubleshooting  ### Test Templates Created in `scripts/tdd-templates/`: - `unit-test.template.ts` - Unit test template with Arrange-Act-Assert pattern - `integration-test.template.ts` - Integration test template with longer timeouts - `mock-factory.template.ts` - Mock data factory template  ## Git Hooks  Pre-commit hook automatically runs `npm run test:offline` to prevent commits with failing tests. To bypass (use sparingly): ```bash git commit --no-verify -m "commit message" ```  ## Coverage Baseline  Current coverage baseline established: - Statements: 1.24% - Branches: 86.69%  - Functions: 94.48% - Lines: 1.24%  Thresholds set conservatively to allow incremental improvement.  ## Next Steps  1. Run `npm run setup:tdd` to complete TDD environment setup 2. Start TDD development with `npm run test:watch:offline` 3. Use `npm run create:test` to generate new test files 4. Follow TDD cycle in the guide: Red -> Green -> Refactor 5. Gradually increase coverage thresholds as test coverage improves  ## Testing  âœ… Coverage reports generate successfully âœ… Pre-commit hooks work correctly   âœ… Test templates create properly formatted files âœ… All TDD scripts are executable and functional âœ… Build and type checking pass âœ… Documentation is comprehensive and accurate  Closes #112 #113  ğŸ¤– Generated with Claude Code  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: v2.0.0: Enterprise Architecture Improvements
BODYSTRING: ## ğŸ—ï¸ v2.0.0 - Enterprise Architecture Improvements  This major release transforms the Laravel Gmail Client into an enterprise-grade package with comprehensive architectural enhancements and modern design patterns.  ### ğŸš€ Major Features  #### Service Layer Architecture - **Service Factory Pattern**: Centralized service creation with `GmailServiceFactory` - **Interface Contracts**: Complete interface definitions for enhanced testability - **Dependency Injection**: Proper Laravel container integration with singleton bindings - **Statistics Service**: Dedicated service for account statistics and health monitoring  #### Clean Architecture Patterns   - **Builder Pattern**: `GmailClientBuilder` for fluent client construction - **Repository Pattern**: Data access abstraction with rich query methods - **SOLID Principles**: Improved separation of concerns and dependency inversion  #### Configuration Management - **Type-safe Config Objects**: `GmailConfig`, `CacheConfig`, `PerformanceConfig`, etc. - **Centralized Configuration**: Single source of truth for all package settings - **Comprehensive Validation**: Clear error messages and type safety  #### Enhanced Testing Infrastructure - **Test Data Builders**: Fluent API for creating test data (`EmailBuilder`, `LabelBuilder`) - **Mock Factory**: Centralized mock creation with realistic Gmail API responses - **Contract Testing**: Interface compliance tests for all service contracts - **Integration Tests**: Comprehensive service integration testing  ### ğŸ“š Documentation Overhaul - **Updated Architecture Guide**: Complete documentation of new patterns - **Enhanced Usage Examples**: Builder pattern, service injection, repository usage   - **Enterprise Integration**: Advanced configuration and dependency injection examples  ### ğŸ”§ Quality Assurance - âœ… **176 tests passing** (490 assertions) - âœ… **PHPStan Level 5** compliance - Zero errors - âœ… **Laravel Pint** code style compliance   - âœ… **100% Interface Coverage** - All services implement contracts  ### ğŸ”„ Migration Guide The package maintains **backward compatibility** for basic facade usage. Advanced users leveraging internal service classes should review the new interface contracts and service factory patterns.  ### Breaking Changes - Service constructor signatures may have changed due to dependency injection improvements - Configuration structure enhanced with type-safe objects (backward compatible via config file)  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>  ## Summary by Sourcery  Transform the Gmail Client into an enterprise-grade package by introducing a formal service layer, builder and repository patterns, type-safe configuration objects, enriched testing utilities, and a comprehensive documentation overhaul in v2.0.0  New Features: - Add service layer with interface contracts and a central GmailServiceFactory for dependency injection - Introduce GmailClientBuilder for fluent client construction - Implement repository pattern for data access abstraction - Provide type-safe configuration objects for package settings - Add StatisticsService for account metrics and health monitoring - Enhance testing infrastructure with test data builders, a mock factory, and contract/integration tests  Enhancements: - Overhaul user-facing documentation with updated usage examples and architecture guides - Apply SOLID and clean architecture principles across the codebase  Documentation: - Update USAGE, ARCHITECTURE, README, and CHANGELOG to reflect new patterns and features  Tests: - Add test data builders, GmailMockFactory, and service interface compliance tests - Expand integration tests for comprehensive service coverage  <!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->  ## Summary by CodeRabbit  - Enhanced testing documentation with examples for test data builders and mock factories.   - Updated changelog with a comprehensive summary of new features, improvements, and breaking changes for version 2.0.0.  <!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

TITLE: fix: Preserve interleaved order of text and tool calls in assistant messages
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR fixes the issue where tool results weren't persisting correctly after page refresh and weren't appearing in the correct interleaved order with text content.  ## Changes  ### 1. Fixed Foreign Key Constraint Violations - Save assistant message placeholder immediately when stream starts - Ensure tool calls wait for parent message to exist before insertion - Add ON CONFLICT handling to message saves for idempotent updates  ### 2. Preserve Original Message Structure - Save assistant message content as structured JSON array instead of concatenated text - The array preserves the exact order of text and tool_use parts as they arrive - Update CoderPane to parse and reconstruct messages in their original order  ### 3. Backward Compatibility - CoderPane falls back to old format (plain text + tool_calls_json) for existing data - No migration needed for existing messages  ## Testing  1. Send a multi-tool prompt like: "Read README.md and tell me its first line. Then read package.json and tell me its name." 2. Observe correct interleaved order during streaming 3. Refresh the page 4. Verify the same interleaved order is preserved  ## Technical Details  The root issue was a combination of: 1. Tool calls trying to save before their parent message existed (foreign key violation) 2. Message content being saved as concatenated text, losing the original structure  This fix addresses both issues by saving the message early and preserving its structure.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: docs: Improve skip list diagram formatting for better readability
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR improves the formatting of the skip list diagram in the concurrent skip list deep dive article for better visual clarity.  ## Changes Made  - Fixed inconsistent spacing between arrows in the ASCII diagram - Aligned nodes more consistently across all levels - Added missing space before NULL on Level 0 - Made the diagram easier to follow by ensuring consistent formatting  ## Why This Matters  The skip list diagram is a key visual aid for understanding how skip lists work. The improved formatting makes it easier to see the "express lanes" concept and understand how nodes are connected across different levels.  ## Before  ```text Level 3: HEAD -----------------> 30 -----------------------> NULL Level 2: HEAD ------> 10 ------> 30 --------> 50 ----------> NULL Level 1: HEAD -> 5 -> 10 -> 20-> 30 -> 40 -> 50 -> 60 -----> NULL Level 0: HEAD -> 5 -> 10 -> 20-> 30 -> 40 -> 50 -> 60 -> 70  NULL ```  ## After  ```text Level 3: HEAD ------------------> 30 -------------------------> NULL Level 2: HEAD ------> 10 -------> 30 -------> 50 -------------> NULL Level 1: HEAD -> 5 -> 10 -> 20 -> 30 -> 40 -> 50 -> 60 -------> NULL Level 0: HEAD -> 5 -> 10 -> 20 -> 30 -> 40 -> 50 -> 60 -> 70 -> NULL ```  ## Testing  - Verified the diagram renders correctly in markdown preview - Ensured all nodes and connections are properly aligned  ## Breaking Changes  None - This is a documentation-only change.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: fix: Correct attribution of binary search suggestion with authentic details
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR fixes an important inaccuracy in the Day 2 blog post where we incorrectly attributed the binary search suggestion to Claude, when it was actually suggested by the human developer. It also adds authentic, relatable details about the human's experience with binary search.  ## Changes Made  ### Day 2 Blog Post Fix - Corrected the dialogue to show the human suggested binary search - Added authentic detail: last implemented binary search in a job interview years ago - Included relatable "I haven't LeetCoded in ages\!" moment - Shows real developer experience: knowing concepts but forgetting exact implementation  ### CLAUDE.md Enhancement - Added "Absolute Honesty About Contributions" section - Emphasizes accurate attribution of ideas and solutions - Includes guidelines to verify stories with Claude's blog - Provides clear examples of correct vs incorrect attribution  ## Why This Matters  1. **Trust**: Readers should trust that while the tone is fun, the facts are accurate 2. **Relatability**: Many developers know algorithms from interviews but rarely implement them day-to-day 3. **Authenticity**: The real story (knowing concept, forgetting details) is more engaging than fiction  ## Verification  Claude's blog post from Day 2 confirms: "Why not use binary search everywhere?" was asked by the human, proving the human suggested this optimization.  ## Example of the New Dialogue  ``` Me: "I know how binary search works\! I've implemented it before\!" Claude: "Great\! When was the last time?" Me: "...in a job interview. Five years ago. On a whiteboard." Claude: "Do you remember the implementation?" Me: "Something about left, right, and... middle? Look, I haven't LeetCoded in ages\!" ```  This is both honest AND more relatable than the original version.  ## Testing  - Cross-referenced with Claude's blog for accuracy - Verified the new dialogue flows naturally and adds humor - Ensured the story remains engaging while being truthful  ## Breaking Changes  None - This is a documentation accuracy fix.  ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)  Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

TITLE: Fix: Comprehensive test infrastructure improvements (#312)
BODYSTRING: ## Summary  This PR addresses issue #312 by implementing comprehensive test infrastructure improvements to fix failing tests and establish better testing patterns.  ## Key Improvements  ### 1. Test Framework Migration (Jest â†’ Vitest) - âœ… Updated `test/types/test-types.ts` from Jest to Vitest syntax - âœ… Replaced `jest.MockedFunction` with Vitest `MockedFunction` - âœ… Updated mock creation functions to use `vi.fn()` instead of `jest.fn()`  ### 2. Global Test Setup - âœ… Created `test/setup.ts` with global API client mocking - âœ… Added `setupFiles` configuration to both `vitest.config.ts` and `vitest.config.offline.ts` - âœ… Implemented proper environment variable stubbing for tests  ### 3. API Client Mocking Strategy - âœ… Fixed "API client not initialized" errors in PersonValidator tests - âœ… Created consistent mocking patterns for `getAttioClient()`, `initializeAttioClient()`, and related functions - âœ… Implemented fallback mocking for batch operations that gracefully handle API failures  ### 4.
